awd_titl_txt: LIT:   Collaborative research: Integrating physiological and genetic mechanisms to understand the evolution of cold tolerance
awd_abstract_narration: The world is changing at an unprecedented pace. Climate change projections predict both higher average temperatures and a greater frequency of extreme weather events (e.g., hot, cold, dry, etc.). The ability of animal populations to survive such changes rests on how much genetic and physiological variation they possess for environmental tolerance. As the climate changes, predicting the responses of animal populations to thermal change will require understanding the consequences of thermal stress at fine scale genetic and physiological levels. Thus, the main objective of this project is to characterize mechanistically the genetic and physiological bases of thermotolerance with the long-term goal of predicting and monitoring mechanistic changes in animal populations in real time. The model fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, is well suited for this research because it is widely distributed and shows the capacity to adapt to novel thermal conditions in the field and laboratory while also being genetically and physiologically tractable. The immediate aims of this project are to: 1) Identify genomic regions harboring natural genetic variation affecting cold tolerance in nature; 2) Test current hypotheses about biochemical and physiological mechanisms underlying the evolution of cold tolerance; and 3) Integrate the complex data sets generated by genomic screens and hypothesis-directed physiological and biochemical assays to identify the candidate genes that matter for the evolution of cold tolerance. Linking whole-organism thermotolerance and physiological mechanisms of tolerance with genetic variation in these candidate genes will provide a foundation for understanding the capacity for animal populations to adapt to a changing climate. The project will also provide educational opportunities for young scientists at multiple levels.

por.por_cntn:
The world is changing at an unprecedented pace. Climate projections predict both higher average temperatures and a greater frequency of extreme weather events (e.g., hot, cold, dry, etc.). Thus, the ability of animal populations to survive such changes rests on how much genetic and physiological variation they possess for environmental tolerance. The ability to predict the responses of animal populations to thermal change will require understanding the consequences of thermal stress at fine scale genetic and physiological levels. Thus, the main objective of this project is to characterize mechanistically the genetic and physiological bases of thermotolerance with the long-term goal of predicting and monitoring mechanistic changes in animal populations in real time. We used the model fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, as it is well suited for this research because it is widely distributed and shows the capacity to adapt to novel thermal conditions in the field and laboratory while also being genetically and physiologically tractable. The goals of this project were to characterize the genetic basis of natural genetic variation in cold tolernace, to mechanistically link these genes with changes in gene expression and metabolic networks, and to functionally validate the findings of the first two aims via the analysis of mutations in the genes of interest.  On many levels this project was a great success, we were able to show that the genetic basis of cold tolerance in flies is controlled by a large number of genes, these genes are largely unique among different types of thermal traits, however some thermal traits are highly connected at the genetic level.  These results are exciting because they suggest that certain thermal traits change change independently over time, while others will change together. We were able to independently validate many of these genes via mutational analysis using publically available fruit fly stocks and these results reveal an identical pattern.  Finally, we wanted to investigate how an organism copes with an thermal environmental stress in real time and so we investigated how all the genes and metabolites change during a thermal shift.  That is how a fly responds to moving into and out of a cold environment, we saw a complex yet repeatable set of gene expression and metabolite changes occur over time and between animals with different tolerances to low temperature.  Taken together our results have been able to link whole-organism thermotolerance and physiological mechanisms of tolerance with genetic variation in these candidate genes and begin to develop  a foundation for understanding the capacity for animal populations to respond to a changing thermal environment.

In addition to the research aims of this proposal we were able to broadly disseminate the results of this research via outreach activites and collaborations with secondary educators in Kansas. These outreach activites were developed as collaborations with secondary educators, by bringing high school teachers to the lab to work with the project staff to incorperate various aspects of Drosophila biology, thermal biology, and genetics into their high school biology classrooms. In addition to this outreach the project also trained many young scientists (undergraduate students to postdoctoral resarch fellows).
